dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The perfect portrait of New England in springtime bloom, awash in a soft mid-morning light. All is deathly quiet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every streetlight extinguished. Not a car on the road. Not a soul to be seen. Rows of shops closed for business. Their storefront windo eerily pristine, adorned with classic Americana kitsch. Two empty rocking chairs tremble in the breeze. A flock of sparrows coasts overhead, beyond the web of tangled branches. A v-formation of little black and brown specks soaring the skies, returning home for the season. PRE-LAP: Tick. Tick. Tick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A wall clock, keeping time. It’s cozy in here, but not warm. A palpable chill hangs o the lived-in parlor. Nobody’s been by in some time. Four beaming, airbrushed faces in a framed photograph on mantelpiece. Father, mother, two-point-five kids. The glass on the frame is just barely frosted over. ANGLE on the FRONT DOOR. From outside: A pair of muted FOOTSTEPS. The adjacent window QUIVERS as a small SCREWDRIVER slides underneath the sill. It’s a tight fit. The screwdriver’s shaft SCISSORS back a forth, slowly forcing its way through. GRINDING the sill’ hardwood base into FLAKES, misting through the air like s A GLOVED HAND reaches into the newly formed crevice, angl its way toward the front door. TWISTING the LOCK...  The door swings open, revealing a MAN, early 30s, on the porch. He wears a fleece jacket, baggy workman jeans and hiking boots. Thick-framed glasses. Average build. This is DEL. He scuffs his boots on the floor mat. Surveys the room. His eyes land on the ticking wall clock. He plucks the cl from its moorings. Removes the batteries. The ticking sound abruptly dies. He re-hangs the clock. Straightens it. He deposits the batteries in a zip-lock bag. Folds the ba into the front pocket of a worn Kipling backpack. Swings backpack over his shoulder. The ape keychain dangles at Del’s side, open-mouthed in a state of perpetual awe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Del rummages clinically through the empty home. He strips the batteries from the smoke alarm. From Daddy' electric toothbrush. From the kids’ toy RCs and night lig and mobile gaming consoles. From Mommy’s vibrator. He neglects the wad of cash on the dresser. The jewelry. flat-screen television. He scans the bookshelf, index finger outstretched. Plucks the more obscure titles. He removes the family portrait from its frame. Sets the f upright just where he found it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Del kneels in the grass, a surgical mask over his nose an mouth. He’s spray-painting a large white X across the law He gets to his feet. Brushes the dirt from his knees. Str off his gloves, revealing two pale, bony hands. We pull back to see every single house on the block, all way to the end of the street, marked with the exact same

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Del stands at the edge of the water, stark naked, hosing himself down with a portable camping shower. EXT. DEL’S TRUCK - DAY Six buckets of fresh lake water rattle in the rear enclos of Del’s pick-up truck. Del brakes at an intersection. Looks both ways. Continues

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Del coasts the aisles with a shopping cart. Most of the grocery’s stock is still in place, though the fluorescent lights, fridges and freezers are down. He checks expiration dates. Takes only what he needs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Del’s truck pulls to a stop outside the town library.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Del replenishes the AAA batteries in his Brother P-Touch® Label Maker. He traverses the stacks, adding the books from his haul t the library’s inventory. Labeling them with their proper Dewey Decimal codes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A wide assortment of plants, shrubs and vegetation. Del circulates, spritzing each of them with water. He listens closely. The roots purr and gurgle under their soil, lapping up the new liquid. He savors the sound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Del pilots a heavy-duty street sweeper up and down the ro its twin brushes WHIRRING and GRINDING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Del sits on the floor, piecing together a complicated jig puzzle of a nautical tableau. We pull back to discover the room is carpeted with a seemingly endless collection of puzzles, all completed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun’s last light casts intense and powerful streaks across the sky. A lone sailboat bobs on the ocean’s surfa Del’s bare feet hang from the boat’s edge as he reads one his books. His nose swathed in layers of sunblock. His fishing rod STIRS. Del JUMPS. He abandons his book, grabbing hold of the rod and reelin his line, mad with excitement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A toy aquarium, battery-operated, filled with plastic clownfish and glowing neon blue water. Del’s curled up on a hammock in the darkness, munching on well-balanced meal of cooked fish, brown rice and veggies He watches an old screwball comedy on a laptop. Chuckles through mouthfuls of food. He keeps an eye on the laptop’s battery power. It’s dwind at nineteen percent. A mammoth pile of unused laptops and portable DVD players rests beside his hammock, stacked like pancakes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Del spreads out on a blanket, gazing up at the nighttime Every single star is visible, every constellation defined awesome natural panorama that belongs to Del and Del alon He falls asleep smiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Del shaves in the mirror. Clips his fingernails. Tweezes eyebrows. Swabs the wax from his ears. He pops two gummy vitamins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Del jogs past rows and rows of suburban houses marked wit his white xX. He crosses into a new part of town, where the front lawns still bare. Unexplored territory. Del stops to catch his breath. He scans the area. Listens Hears movement. He turns, alarmed. It’s the window blinds from a nearby house. They’re rustl scratching softly against the glass... Somebody’s inside. Del approaches the porch, moving furtively. He presses his ear to the door. From the other side -- something’s CLAWING against the do paneling. Something low to the ground. Del thinks. He turns the knob. The door’s unlocked. He pushes it open A small DOG bursts forth, wild with newfound freedom. Paw frantically at Del’s leg. Eyes wide and watery. It’s a pug, and a fat one at that. Filthy. Rabid with ene And its sharp talons, long ungroomed and ill-maintained, DEEP into Del’s SKIN... Del shakes the thing off his leg. Nudges it outside with leg. Shuts the door behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Del instantly GAGS. This place REEKS. It’s PUTRID.  Flies circling in droves. Dog shit everywhere. Del whips the surgical mask over his nose and mouth. He breathes heavily, his eyes pooling from the stench. He makes his way through the house. Steps over a big, bul bag of DOG KIBBLE -- year’s supply -- it’s been CLAWED IN He proceeds cautiously into the kitchen. The flies’ buzzi amplifies, grows DEAFENING... There it is. Slumped across the tiled floor, contorted in awkward, awful position... a BODY. A woman. Very old. Very dead. Del processes the gruesome scene. He continues into the living room. There’s a second body, slouched over in a leather armchai Head facing away from Del and toward the defunct televisi A halo of flies overhead, almost angelic. The husband. Also very old. Also very dead. The TV remote still locked in his hand. Del pulls away the surgical mask. Squats down to meet the rotting corpse face-to-face. The man’s eyes are marbled over, glazed white. Del shimmies the remote from the man’s ice-cold hand. Pop out the batteries. Pockets them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Del hops over the woman’s body to the trash drawer. Extra the garbage bags all at once. He sweeps up the mess. Scrubs the floor. Collects the dog droppings and scattered pet food into the bags. He yanks the rug out from under the furniture. Tears out shower curtain. Wraps the bodies into them, burrito-style He pulls the couple’s yellowed wedding portrait from its frame. They look youthful, happy. He replaces the empty frame on the bureau.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Del takes out the trash. He pauses at the sight of the fat pug dog, sitting eagerl the curb. Staring back at him. Tail wagging. INT. DEL’S TRUCK - DAY Del loads the bodies into the back of his truck. The dog’s seated in the passenger seat, gazing out somber at the newly sprayed white X on its owners’ lawn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Del off-loads the bodies into the dirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Del digs a hole with a well-worn shovel. The dog watches at his side, panting. INT. DEL’S TRUCK - DAY Del returns to his truck. He looks in the side mirror. The dog’s pacing the woods in circles, sniffing around at patch of fresh grave. Del starts his car. The dog looks up. Del turns away. Starts driving. The dog barks, strained. Chases after the truck with effo its stubby legs giving out easily. Del accelerates, staring forward. The dog’s barking grows distant in his wake. He flinches. Takes his foot off the gas. Allows the dog t catch up to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Del dumps a bucket of water over the dog.  He grooms the dog’s nails with a small pair of scissors. He peeks under the dog’s hood. It’s male. He prints out a label. Affixes it to the dog’s new collar. “NAME: DEWEY.”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Del walks Dewey on a leash. Dewey circles a fire hydrant with mild interest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Del and Dewey play fetch. Dewey moves very slowly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Del eats a home-cooked meal at a cluster of desks, readin library book on pet care. Dewey lingers at his feet. Del feeds him a baby carrot. INT. CHILDREN’S SECTION - LIBRARY - NIGHT Del installs Dewey in an enclosed pen outfitted with bean cushions and a bowl of water. Dewey roams the perimeter, restless. Del exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Del picks from an assortment of colorful chew toys. Tests their squeaking capabilities. INT. CHILDREN’S SECTION - LIBRARY - DAY Del returns to Dewey’s pen with a shopping bag filled wit toys and treats. He stops. The bean bags are TORN APART. Beans EVERYWHERE. Water bowl OVERTURNED. The pen’s BREACHED... Dewey’s GONE Del rounds a corner. A shred of paper catches on his shoe inspects it -- it’s a page from a picture book. Ripped apart. Destroyed.  He looks ahead. Sees the remnants of an entire stock of children’s books, all RIPPED to SHREDS. Del panics. He sinks to his hands and knees. Tries to gat the scraps and re-order them. It’s a hollow task. They’re all ruined. Del starts to tear up. He turns. Dewey’s gazing at him. Munching on one of the pages. Unrepentant. Del takes a deep breath. INT. DEL’S TRUCK - DAY Del drives, steadfast. In the passenger seat: An overflowing trash bag filled wi every last one of the pet supplies. He peers in the rearview. Dewey stares back at him, curio

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Del parks his car for the evening. He’s alone now. INT. CHILDREN’S SECTION - LIBRARY - NIGHT Del surveys the empty space where Dewey’s pen once was. He smooths out the creases in the carpet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Del re-files the books on pet care.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Del watches another old screwball comedy. He doesn’t laugh. Shuts the laptop.  10.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s a windy day at sea. Del’s sailboat rocks with the wa swaying up and down. Del shrouds himself in a blanket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Del eats dinner in silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Del stares at the plastic fish in his toy aquarium, swimm back and forth, smiles etched on their faces. He turns on his side in the hammock. Tries to sleep. Just then: A low RASP. Barely audible. Del perks up. He scrambles to his TRANSISTOR RADIO. Tunes to the correct frequency. The sound sharpens. It’s a VOICE.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hello? Del’s eyes widen.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Can anyone hear me? Del watches the radio in awe.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Please. Please, somebody be there. Del grabs the radio. Holds down the talk button. Opens hi mouth to speak... He falters.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: (weak) No. Del takes his finger off the button.

dialogues.speaker: DEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No. He SMASHES the RADIO.  11.

dialogues.speaker: DEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No. He chokes. Hyperventilates. Inhales sharply.

dialogues.speaker: DEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh god. Oh god. Suddenly: BANG. BANG. BANG. From outside. Sounds like a HAIL of GUNFIRE. Del BOLTS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Del rushes out onto the roof, just in time to catch the mighty FIREWORKS DISPLAY on the HORIZON. The night sky is RIDDLED with TECHNICOLOR. The stars flus away, overwhelmed by the dramatic BARRAGE of LIGHT and SO Rockets soaring upward and rippling through the atmospher exploding violently, shredding the heavens... It’s BLINDI Del shields his face. Covers his ears. Screams. His voice is DROWNED OUT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Del barricades the door. Blacks out the window with thick strips of duct tape, immersing himself in TOTAL DARKNESS. We can still hear the fireworks in full force outside. Del locks himself in a stall, curling his knees up into h chest. He gropes a SWITCHBLADE in his hand. His grip is shaky, unstable. The knife drops to the floor landing with a small CLINK. Del shuts his eyes. Takes a series of deep breaths.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: (in SOTTO) Please. Please no.  12.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The radio, smashed into pieces, crackles quietly.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (distorted) Can you hear me now? The receiver light fizzles out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Del wakes up. It’s quiet outside. He takes a peek through the window. The skies are clear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Del sidles out from the library’s double doors. There’s no one in sight. He listens closely. Hears a sound, very distant. It’s a CAR ALARM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A terrible wreck. There’s a STATION WAGON up on the curb, FLATTENED under a felled LAMPPOST. Windshield SMASHED IN. Engine FUMING. The alarm BLARES. Del approaches cautiously, knife outstretched. The driver's incapacitated. Maybe dead. Del squints for a better look. The driver is female. Almo certainly the woman from the radio. He edges closer. She’s young. Late teens or so. Gash on h forehead. Looks nasty. Probably dead. Del opens the car door.  13. The body slumps out into Del’s arms. He checks for a pulse... Her eyes flicker open. They stare at one another.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: You're here. She smiles.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m gonna fuck you into the next dimension. She laughs. Slips back into unconsciousness. Del sets her down in the grass, taking care not to bang h head. Returns to the car. The dash is papered with deflated potato chip bags and em liquor bottles and stray undergarments. He looks in the backseat, spots her transistor radio. Her leftover fireworks. A Polaroid camera. A GameBoy. Two bul floral-print suitcases, frayed at the seams. He pops the glove compartment. Finds a small HANDGUN, bur among loose papers. He peers over his shoulder at the young woman splayed out the grass. Contemplates his next move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Del unzips the suitcases. Sifts through the wrinkled clot and toiletries. He uncovers a weathered PHOTO of a FAMILY. Taped together places -- it looks as if it’s been torn up before. The girl. Her mother, father, little sister. All smiles. Underneath, he finds a newer series of overexposed Polaro selfies taken at various iconic national landmarks. In ea of them, the girl mugs for the camera with a ridiculous f He lingers on a photo taken at the crest of the Grand Can She's sticking her tongue out at him. This is GRACE.  14.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grace stirs awake. Her vision stabilizes. She's in a BEDROOM, sparsely decorated. The windows are BOARDED SHUT from the outside. A sliver of DAYLIGHT pours from a neglected crack. She sits up with pain. Runs her hand through her hair. He forehead’s dressed in layers of GAUZE. It STINGS. She gets to her feet. Feels DIZZY. Grabs a trash can, dig her head in. HURLS.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Ugh. Fuck me. She wipes her mouth. Heads to the door. Reaches for the k It’s LOCKED. She RAPS her FISTS on the DOOR.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hello? Hello--? Nothing. She flings open the dresser drawers. They’re all EMPTY. The room’s been cleaned out completely. The only spare it bottle of hand sanitizer on the night stand. She hears a pair of FOOTSTEPS. Turns back to the door. Se shadow pass across the small round PEEPHOLE.

dialogues.speaker: DEL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Is there anyone else?

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: What’s going on?

dialogues.speaker: DEL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Answer my question, please.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: What’s your question?

dialogues.speaker: DEL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Is there anyone else?

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: It’s just me in here.

dialogues.speaker: DEL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I know that already.  15.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Oh, so it’s my fault your question was fucking stupid. The shadow disappears from the peephole.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Wait!

dialogues.speaker: DEL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Is there anybody else?

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: There’s no one else.

dialogues.speaker: DEL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Anywhere? Grace’s eyes narrow in on the door.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Are you not--

dialogues.speaker: DEL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Anywhere? There’s a hint of panic in his voice. Grace processes. She exhales slowly.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Anywhere.

dialogues.speaker: DEL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: It's just you?

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Just me and you.

dialogues.speaker: DEL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: That’s all?

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Yeah. That’s it. We’re it. A long pause on the other end.

dialogues.speaker: DEL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Why are you still alive?  16.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Del stands on the other end of the door, watching Grace through the peephole’s fishbowl POV. Grace looks directly at him.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Why are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grace waits. Finally, Del speaks up.

dialogues.speaker: DEL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: What about the gun?

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Gun? Which gun?

dialogues.speaker: DEL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: The gun in your glove compartment.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Oh, that gun. I found it on the road a few months back. I figured maybe it’d come in handy one day.

dialogues.speaker: DEL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Against who?

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Well... who’s to say they don’t all come back from the dead and try to eat our brains?

dialogues.speaker: DEL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: That won’t happen.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: DEL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Because it doesn’t happen.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: And the entire human population of earth dropping dead in a single instant on a Tuesday afternoon, does that not happen either? No response.  17.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Will you let me out?

dialogues.speaker: DEL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I can’t yet.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Come on, man. (a pause) I‘1l make it worth your while. She lets the last word linger.

dialogues.speaker: DEL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I’m going to unlock the door. That'll cue you to start counting to fifteen Mississippi. I’1l be counting too, from farther away. After fifteen Mississippi you can open the door. I won’t be here. Don’t look for me.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Hold on.

dialogues.speaker: DEL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: There's a car outside, it’s got a full tank of gas and all your belongings, minus the gun. You shouldn’t have that.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Dude, what the fuck--?

dialogues.speaker: DEL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You have to leave. You have to leave and forget you were ever here and never come back. Please.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: But... we’re all that’s left.

dialogues.speaker: DEL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I’m going to start counting now.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Are you listening to me? I said we're the only ones still out here! We’re the sole fuckin’ survivors, man! You can’t just ghost me like we're in fucking middle school--!

dialogues.speaker: DEL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: One Mississippi.  18. The doorknob CLICKS.

dialogues.speaker: DEL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I'm leaving now, two Missi-- Grace opens the door. Meets Del head-on. Smirks.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: You're tall.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: You sounded shorter.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: Please go back inside and close the door, this isn’t right. It’s not what we talked about.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: You're bossy too. We can work around that.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: There’s nothing to work around. You're leaving.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: You think it’s a coincidence we found each other?

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: No. You were drinking and you crashed your car on my street.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Ah, that’s right.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: It’s not funny. In your drunken binge you took down a lamppost, and now I have to fix it. That’s going to require substantial renovations and-- and considerable labor--

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Labor.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: Yes. Manpower.  19.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Man-power.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: Stop that.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: C’mon. You know as well as I do why He kept the two of us alive.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: Who? Who kept us alive? Grace points upward.

dialogues.speaker: DEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Wow. Okay.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Haven’t you ever heard of “be fruitful and--

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: --and multiply,” yes. It’s from the King James Bible, Genesis 1:28, call two twenty fifty-two.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: What’s that?

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: It was an English translation commissioned by King James I in the early sixteenth century-- or maybe the seventeenth--

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Not the Bible, the number.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: Genesis 1:28 is where the passage appears in the text.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: The second one. The two-twenty whatever you said...

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: Two twenty fifty-two. It’s the call number for that edition.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Call number?  20.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: Every book has one.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: They do? Are you sure?

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: Yes, I’m very sure. I don’t really have time to talk to you anymore--

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Are you retarded or something? Del SNAPS.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: Fuck off. Okay? Just... please leave me alone. I have a lot of work to do today. I’m already behind schedule, even without factoring in the lamppost.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: I can’t believe this.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: The engine’s running in your car. You're wasting gas.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Right. And that’s bad for the environment. He gives her a look. She laughs.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: You're making fun of me.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: I've gotta go. He turns to leave. Grace’s smile fades.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: No. Come on. Del starts down the stairs.  21.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You're making me feel like I'ma fucking asshole or-- hey, listen, I’m sorry-- will you wait a minute? Del quickens his pace. Grace follows him outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grace steps out into the light. She looks around in awe. Del hands She turns

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Oh my god. her the car keys. She barely notices.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This is where you live? You really live here all alone?

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Where are the bodies?

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: Which ones?

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Which ones? All of them. Everyone died where they stood, all at once. No warnings, no symptoms, just-- to Del.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You can barely drive a mile without getting one of them caught in your tires. Everywhere you look it’s just piles and piles of bodies. And the smell, that god-awful smell that’s everywhere... She inhales the cool air.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s not here.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: Nope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: I buried them.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: All of them? Alone? That’s impossible.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: No, it’s just tedious. I started with the public spaces. The outdoor areas. Then I moved on to the shops and restaurants and offices. As of late I’ve been clearing out the residences. The town’s population was 9,539. I’m at 8,840. That’s a 92% clearance rate thus far. It’s actually 92.6, but I round down.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: Rounding up would be giving myself more credit than I deserve.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: No. I mean, why did you bury all the bodies?

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: (matter-of-fact) They smelled. They were ugly. So I got rid of them. Grace thinks.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: I want to stay.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: That's not possible.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Don’t you ever get lonely? Del cracks a smirk.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: No. I don’t get lonely.  23.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: You're... you’re telling me you’re totally fine allowing the human race to go extinct?

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: It’s out of my hands.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Did you fall asleep during sex ed? I’m game, man. DTF. You don’t even have to buy me dinner first. She extends her arms outward.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Take me, you bastard.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: Okay. How old are you?

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Nineteen. I think. It’s been hard to keep track.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: Great. So the average age of menopause is fifty-one. That gives us roughly thirty-two years in which we can propagate.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: I love it when you talk dirty.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: Oh, I’m just getting started. Now best case scenario, my sperm’s hyper-virile, we max out our capacity and have you on rotation twelve months out of the year. Grace winces.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: You want to put me on rotation? Like a cow?

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: Don’t look at me. I’m just fleshing out your repopulation theory to its logical extreme.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Right. Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, assuming none are multiple births, no twins or triplets in the mix, that’s forty-two children maximum. Right? I think that’s right. We can get a calculator.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Oh no, I trust your data.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: Great. So that’s forty-two of our children that are then obligated to breed with their siblings to further procreate. And due to the heightened risk of developmental disabilities in inbred children, our descendants would have a severely diminished capacity for survival and would likely die out within a matter of one or two generations, max.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: You don’t know that.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: Of course I do.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: It worked before. Del shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: I don’t believe in myth. It’s good literature, that’s all.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: How can you be so cynical?

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: I'm a pragmatist. I recommend it highly. Good-bye now-- I’m sorry, what did you say your name was?

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Grace. Grace Wilkins.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: Good-bye, Grace Wilkins. Best of luck out there. Del strolls off.  25.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Del fills his buckets with water. Grace appears beside hi

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: I can help clear the bodies.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: I don’t need help. I’m 92% done.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: You'll get done a lot quicker with an extra pair of hands. And we can start planning our expansion.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: Expansion?

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: To the next town. And the next one after that. I bet we can clear the whole county in no time.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: I’m not interested in clearing the county or any of the other towns. He gets to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: DEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: My obligation starts and ends with this town. It’s my home. It’s been my home as long as I’ve lived. The least I can do is keep it clean.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: But there’s so much else out there.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: That's a subjective opinion.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: When was the last time you left?

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: I’m not sure how that’s important.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: That long, huh? Del doesn’t respond. He hauls the buckets to his truck. G grabs two herself.  26.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m staying here whether you like it or not.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: Why? I’ve been nothing but rude to you all morning.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: I’m an extrovert. I wasn’t built to be alone. You can ignore me all you want, give me the silent treatment, whatever. I don’t need to talk to you. Just let me talk at you. He looks to her.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I need to know there’s someone else that can hear me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Del files books with a pair of noise-cancelling headphone clamped over his ears. Grace trails. He pays her no mind.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: (voice raised) I was making my way up the coast. My aunt got me this guide of the fifty U.S. landmarks you need to see before you die. One per state, and it ends at Niagara Falls. Have you been to Niagara Falls--? He walks right past her into the next aisle. Grace pulls a book from the nearest shelf and inserts it elsewhere, out of alphabetical order. She catches up to Del. Removes his headphones.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You like books?

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: Yeah, I do.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Me too!  27.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: That’s great. He fastens the headphones over his ears once more.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: We should start a book club!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grace watches from the shore as Del sails. She polishes o beer, crushes the can and chucks it into the water. She raises one hand to eye level. Pinches the sailboat wi her index and middle fingers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Del prepares an intricate sushi platter for himself, comp with wasabi, ginger and soy sauce. Grace observes the meal in awe.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Are you eating fish?

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: It’s salmon sashimi. He nips at the fish with a pair of chopsticks.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Some apocalypse this is. She gets up. Browses the stacks.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So why do you think it happened? Why did everyone die like that?

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: No use in speculating. I doubt we'll ever know for sure.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Maybe it was the Rapture.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: Maybe. Probably not. He sucks his chopstick clean.  28.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Where were you when it--?

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: I was sleeping.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: You were sleeping at two-thirty on a Tuesday afternoon?

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: I worked nights.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Where’d you work?

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: Here. I was the night custodian.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Huh.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: It wasn’t so bad. My job was to keep everything in order. I like doing that. And they let me read whatever I wanted in my downtime. It was quiet. It was just me. Grace turns to him.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Didn't you ever feel lonely?

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: That’s the second time you've asked me that.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: I’m curious.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: You're curious? He pivots his chair to her.

dialogues.speaker: DEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You really want to know when I felt lonely? I felt lonely when there were 9,538 other people here, all of them looking at me like I was some kind of martian. Keeping their distance. Whispering to each other. That’s when I felt lonely. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stops. Del nods. She exits. Del folds 29.

dialogues.speaker: DEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Is that what you wanted to hear? Was that answer satisfactory, or would you like to ask me again? Settles.

dialogues.speaker: DEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I didn’t mean to raise my voice.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: It’s okay. I can leave.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: I'll leave you alone. It’s fine. You've clearly got something good going here. Good for you, I mean. You’re happy, and I guess I thought I could-- I don’t know-- at the end of the day it’s not fair for me to put my shit on you. I’m sorry. Grace forces a smile.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I‘'1l go pack my things. his napkin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grace loads the car with her luggage. She gets behind the wheel. Stares forward. Her eyes start to well. She wipes She winds

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Fuck. them clean with the inside of her sleeve.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Fuck me. Okay. the key in the ignition. The car sputters to life. Her foot hits the gas pedal... A tap on the driver's window.  30. It’s Del, crouching down to meet her at eye level.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What? Del cups a hand to his ear. Grace cranks down the window.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: You should put on your brights. It’s dark out there.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Oh. Yeah, thanks. She flicks on the brights.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: See you around.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: You don’t have to go just yet.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: The last thing I need is for you to feel sorry for me. If I get going now I think I can make it to Niagara Falls by sun-up.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: What’s in Niagara Falls?

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: It’s one of the landmarks in my aunt's guidebook. I was telling you earlier-- you must’ve had the headphones on. Anyways, it’s the last one and then that’s it.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: That’s it?

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: It’s my last landmark.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: What happens after that?

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: What do you mean?  31.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: Once you've reached Niagara Falls. Where do you go afterwards? Up to Canada, or--? Grace shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Stop.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: Can you answer my question?

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Why? What does it matter anyway? It’s not like you care.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: You shouldn’t go to Niagara Falls. Not yet. You can stay here for a little while, get your bearings.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Stop. Just stop. Please.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: What kinds of movies do you like?

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Movies?

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: We have a great catalogue of DVDs back at the library. I watch them on laptops, the portable players, anything I can get my hands on. You could borrow one or two of them sometime. The DVDs, I mean. Drop them off in the return slot when you're finished. (a pause) Do you like comedies?

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Yeah. Yeah, I like comedies.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: We've got a whole section that’s just comedy films. And not just the mainstream stuff either. Some of the titles have been out of print for-- well, I guess they’re all out of print now, technically.  32.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Why are you saying all this? I thought you wanted to be alone.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: I do. At the moment, your leaving here and never ever coming back is a very exciting prospect for me.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: But if I’m forced to think about it long-term, I‘1l admit there’s a very slim possibility that there could come a day when I change my mind and decide that I could do with some company after all. But by that point you’d be long gone and it'd be virtually impossible for me to ever find you again.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Okay?

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: There’s a terrifying degree of permanency there, don’t you think?

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: I guess.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: What I’m trying to say is, if you leave now our goose is cooked before it even hatches.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Cooked goose sounds pretty tasty right now.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: I wouldn't know. I’m a pescatarian.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Of course you are. Del shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: We'll give it a try.  33.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Are you sure?

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: No, of course I’m not sure. I’m agreeing to a trial period, during which time we set a very strict series of boundaries. As I believe I've said, I take a great civic pride in keeping this town operational, and I can’t risk my daily routine being disrupted-- Grace gets out of the car. Stares at Del for a long beat.

dialogues.speaker: DEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What? What’s wrong? She gives him a big hug. Del tenses uneasily in her grip.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: I don’t even know your name.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: It’s Del.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Just Del?

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: Yeah. Just Del.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Del rigs a series of cords around the fallen lamppost. He harnesses them to the back of his truck. He hops in his car. Nudges the gas. The lamppost slowly cranes upright. EXT. DEL’S TRUCK - DAY Del brakes at the intersection from earlier. To his surprise, a SECOND CAR wipes right past his, blast an upbeat TUNE from the RADIO. Grace gives a friendly wave. She continues down the road the opposite direction.  34. Del shakes it off. Moves along. He glances in his rearview. Pulls a u-turn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Del sees Grace’s car parked outside of a house with a bumblebee mailbox. The lawn is unmarked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Del hastens inside.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: Grace--? All of a sudden, a LARGE MASS plummets out from the secon floor, TUMBLING like a SLINKY down the STAIRCASE, landing right at DEL’S FEET. He looks down. It’s a BODY.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Sleep well? Grace appears at the top of the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Clearing the house. I didn’t see a white X on the lawn, so I figured it was up for grabs. She vanishes down a hallway.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I couldn't have picked a better one to pop my cherry either. This lady's got loads of good shit. I think she might be a hoarder.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: Wait a minute. Grace doubles back into view.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Is everything all right?  35.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: No. No, it’s not “all right.” He meets her halfway up the staircase. Del sighs.

dialogues.speaker: DEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Let’s get one thing straight. Clearing the houses, that’s my job. I do that by myself. You see an unmarked lawn, you stay away.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: I’m trying to help.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: And I appreciate that. I really do. But there’s a very particular way that this needs to get done.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: That’s fine. Show me what to do.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: Wouldn't you rather just watch a movie or something?

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: No, I want the civic pride crap. I'd like to serve as a productive member of my community.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: Okay. Follow me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Del extracts the batteries from an electric can opener. H drops them into his zip-lock bag.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: Batteries. They’re the single most important commodity the dead have to offer.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: The necrophiliac in me would have to argue with you. Del glares at her.  36.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Bad joke.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: This next part is crucial. You might want to hold your breath. He removes the trash bag from the garbage drawer. Flings opens the refrigerator, revealing a menagerie of rotted, moldy food items.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Ugh. So gross. Del begins emptying the fridge contents into the bag.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What the hell are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: Cleaning.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Why? No one’s ever stepping foot in this house again after we leave.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: How do I explain this? Okay. In thermodynamics, there's a term called entropy. It’s understood as a measure of disorder, the capacity for randomness in a given system.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: I took biology in high school. I know what entropy is.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: But have you ever considered its implications? The more entropy in a system, the more potential for chaos. Variables upon variables. Endlessly unpredictable outcomes. But when you reduce the amount of entropy in a system... He strings up the bag with a tight knot.

dialogues.speaker: DEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You can control for error. With every piece of trash we pick up, that’s one less force for disorder in the universe.  37. He hands Grace the bag. Procures another.

dialogues.speaker: DEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Now imagine a system with no disorder whatsoever. In theory you could predict, with stunning accuracy, most everything that will ever happen within that system.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: It’s like a vacuum.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: It’s exactly a vacuum. And so long as we’re committed to serving as agents of order rather than chaos, it stays that way.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: But why would you want to know everything that’s ever gonna happen? That seems so dull.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: It’s comforting. It gives me peace. (a pause) That’s just me though. He moves on to the next room, leaving Grace to process.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Del peruses the bookshelves. He cradles an extensive handwritten inventory binder in one hand.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Can I see that?

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: Knock yourself out. Grace scans the binder. At first glance, it’s countless p of utter gibberish. She squints. Del’s handwriting is neat, albeit microscopi Additions are painstakingly scrawled into every margin, a with corresponding call numbers.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: How can you read all this? It’s making me nauseous. Del smirks.  38.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Seriously, dude. This is more than a little cuckoo.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: I’m a completist. Having as full a catalogue as possible is very important to me. He picks a book from the shelf. Examines the back cover. Plops it into his backpack.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: But you can’t possibly read all these books. Not in one lifetime.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: Is that a challenge?

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: No. God no. Del steps back from the shelves.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: You didn’t see anything upstairs, did you? Any books, larger books, maybe by her bedside?

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: I wasn’t really paying attention.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: Hm. I’1l be back. He sprints upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Was there something you were looking for in particular?

dialogues.speaker: DEL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Yes. At the time of her death, Mrs. Lipschitz owed the library over seven hundred dollars in late fees.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Holy fuck. How many books did this lady steal from you?

dialogues.speaker: DEL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: One.  39.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Del searches the bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You charged her seven hundred dollar late fees on a single book? He yanks open the bedside drawer. Nothing but old trinket and travel brochures.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: This was a special book. Are you familiar with Tolstoy?

dialogues.speaker: GRACE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Was he the one they stabbed in the eye with an ice-pick?

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: No, that was Trotsky. Leo Tolstoy was one of the greatest writers to ever walk the earth.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Never heard of him.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: Regardless. Six years ago Mrs. Lipschitz checked out our best edition of War and Peace. Call five eighty-three sixty or so. Fourteen hundred pages. Leather-bound. He reaches deep into the recesses of the adjacent closet.

dialogues.speaker: DEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: She claimed our records were wrong, that she never checked it out in the first place. Eventually we were forced to write it off as a loss. But I always had a feeling... No luck. He withdraws his hand.

dialogues.speaker: DEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: shit.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Found it. Del turns.  40.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Del returns downstairs.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: Where is it? Grace nods to a giant tome propping up the sofa’s bum leg Del’s face falls.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: I guess Tolstoy’s not for everyone. She digs out the book. The sofa collapses on one side.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Here you go. One big, fat copy of War and Peace. She hands Del the book. He looks down at it sadly.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: She stretched out the leather.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Ready to go?

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: Almost. He bends down, lifts the sofa and replaces the weak leg w a small wooden block.

dialogues.speaker: DEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grace lingers in the house. Through the window behind her catch a glimpse of Del spray-painting the front lawn. Her gaze lands on an empty picture frame, sitting upright the mantelpiece. She peers out the window. Watches Del work.  41.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grace stands at the precipice of a freshly dug grave. Del prepares to bury the deceased homeowner.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Shouldn’t we say a few words?

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: We don’t have time. Grace grabs the shovel from Del’s hands.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: You knew her. She was a person. Not just some piece of trash.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: You really believe that?

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Yeah, I do.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: So all those bodies you saw lying in the streets, the ones you told me got caught up in your tires wherever you went-- you didn’t say words for any of them, did you?

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: Exactly.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: But I held my breath.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Every time I saw one of them I held my breath for ten seconds. Like I was driving through a tunnel or something. If I stopped before ten seconds I'd make myself start over from the beginning. It was just this stupid thing I did. I’m not even sure why.  42.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: And what happened when you saw clusters of them all at once?

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: I held for longer. Del nods.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: Okay. He straightens his posture. Inhales deeply. Holds. Grace takes a second to catch on. She follows his lead. They wait. They exhale.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Bye, Mrs. Lipschitz. She lowers the first mound of dirt into the hole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Del enjoys a shower by the lake. Behind him, the water’s surface begins to RIPPLE ever so slightly. He doesn’t notice.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Boo! Grace POPS OUT from UNDER the WATER. Startled, Del TOPPLES into a nearby BUSH.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Whoops. Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grace paces the frozen food aisle, all but cleared out. S frowns at a stray pint of gelato, melted and shriveled.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Man. What I wouldn’t give for some Neapolitan ice cream right now.  43. At the next aisle over, Del examines the granola selectio with a discerning eye.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: What’s that?

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: You're joking, right? The three flavors. You know what this is.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: Maybe. I haven’t got much of a sweet tooth.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: You're lucky. Since I’ve been on the road my two primary food groups are Pop Tarts and potato chips. You should’ve seen what I looked like before the apocalypse. No ass whatsoever. Now? Now I have a donk.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: I hadn't noticed. Grace reaches the wine and spirits aisle. It’s a bottle missing.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Hey Del, you a big drinker?

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: Not so much, no.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: All right. More for me then. She clears the tequila shelf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grace admires the plant life.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: I can’t believe you've been able to keep these alive for so long. Del brushes past her, watering a nearby row of

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: They're owed most of the credit. These are the sole survivors of a particularly harsh winter. pristine. Not gardenias.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grace pokes gently at a bright pink orchid flower.

dialogues.speaker: DEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I do my part in feeding them, but every last plant in this habitat had to make a case for itself. And under suboptimal conditions, they each managed not only to survive but to thrive. Trust me, they wouldn’t be here anymore if they didn’t want to be here. Grace laughs.

dialogues.speaker: DEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What’s funny?

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: I mean, they’re pretty and all, but you're talking about them like they're people. They’re just roots and leaves. They don’t exactly possess the power of free will--

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: Shh. Listen. Del holds the base of the orchid to Grace’s ear. He sprin a few droplets of water on the soil. Grace listens as the roots drink. She smiles.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: They sound happy.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: They are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grace tears open a bag of popcorn kernels. She spreads the kernels out onto a sheet of tin foil. She folds the tin foil into a pouch, affixes it to a stic and hangs it over a campfire. A cacophony of low POPS.  45.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Del powers up one of his laptops, inserts a DVD disc. He turns to Grace, who munches quietly on a bowl of popcorn.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: Tonight’s film is Africa Screams from 1949, starring the great Bud Abbott and Lou Costello. Keep your eyes peeled for Max Baer and Shemp Howard in supporting roles. He takes a breath.

dialogues.speaker: DEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The film has a total runtime of eighty minutes, but we'll enjoy a brief intermission at forty-five minutes as we switch to a new laptop with more battery life. Grace gives a thumbs-up.

dialogues.speaker: DEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Thank you. He sits down beside Grace. The film begins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Del and Grace watch as Abbott and Costello bumble around jungle in ill-fitting safari gear. Del chuckles heartily at each wisecrack. Grace takes a lo sip from her wine glass.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: I'll be right back. Del doesn’t seem to care. Grace heads off into the stacks. She roams aimlessly, arm swinging at her sides. Bored. She stumbles upon a door that reads EMPLOYEES ONLY. A fai neon blue glow pours out from underneath, soaking her toe She inches closer. Opens the door. Peeks her head in.  46. INT. BACK ROOM - LIBRARY —- CONTINUOUS Grace wanders inside the makeshift bedroom. Sees the toy aquarium, the hammock, the pile of laptops. She probes the space. Her gaze falls on a large stack of PHOTOGRAPHS hidden in a dark pocket of the room, bound together with a thick rubber band. She takes a look at the woman in the first photo. It’s Mrs. Lipschitz, on vacation in Italy. The missing photo from the picture frame. Grace pulls off the rubber band. She sifts through the photographs one by one. The first few are familiar to us: the elderly couple's wedding portrait, the airbrushed nuclear family. They're the newest in a stack of hundreds. Grace opens a nearby filing cabinet, revealing an impossi comprehensive collection of similar PHOTOGRAPHS... A town’s worth of people smiling back at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Del and Grace gaze up at the stars from a picnic blanket.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: I never knew there were so many.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: I did.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Why do you keep doing that?

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Never mind. She stretches out on the blanket.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You know I used to pray every night before I went to sleep? (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: GRACE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Me and my sister, we’d kneel down at our beds, clamp our fingers together and we'd pray. My parents too. Real ride-or-die God-fearing folk, we were. My dad was a pastor. He died on the toilet. I’m not really sure what that means... Del turns to her.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: Do you still believe?

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: I have no idea. I’m in the market if you’ve got anything good. Del shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: Just the basic thermodynamics.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Y'know, Del, I envy you.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: You were asleep. All you had to do was wake up, walk outside and find the world changed.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: I guess.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Yeah. Must have been nice. She chugs her wine bottle dry. Sets it off to the side.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'll bet it never even crossed your mind what I was doing when it happened.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: I figured it’d be impolite to ask. Grace grins stupidly. She’s drunk.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: I was with a boy.  48. She gives Del a knowing glare. He slides away from her.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: It’s getting late.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: You don’t want to hear my story?

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: Maybe tomorrow. Grace edges closer.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: You ever fuck a girl in the back of your truck? Pull her panties down over her knees, take her from behind--?

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: Come on. Don’t do that.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: Don’t take this to a vulgar place. We were having a good time.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: I can get you off.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: That’s a bad idea.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Oh, I think it’s an excellent idea. She reaches for him. He gets to his feet. Grace’s smile fades.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What’s wrong?

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: You’ve had too much to drink.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: I know what I’m doing. You don’t have to treat me like a child.  49.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: Then stop acting like one. Grace stands up.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: I get that you’re nervous. It’s okay. I can help you.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: You should get some sleep. We have a long day ahead of us tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Wait.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: Take any of the marked houses. The doors are unlocked. He disappears inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Del paces the room, breathing quickly. His face grows FLUSH. His hands ball into FISTS.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: Fuck. Fuck you. Piece of shit--! He HURLS a dead laptop AGAINST THE WALL, where it SMASHES into PIECES. Takes ANOTHER. SNAPS the thing in HALF. KICK AWAY at his PILE. Parts go FLYING. He stops. Draws the air back into his lungs with effort. Allows his heartbeat to settle, matching the soft pulse o the toy aquarium’s neon blue glow. He glances down at the floor. Assesses the damage. The room’s a MESS. Del shakes his head. Bends down. Starts cleaning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grace listens from outside the door, lips pursed. She exhales coolly. Takes off.  50.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Del brushes his teeth. Spits. His eyes are lined with dark circles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Del walks out into the daylight. He searches the block. No sign of Grace anywhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grace changes into a sweatshirt. Stuffs stray belongings her suitcase. Forces the old thing closed. Zips. She examines the tattered photo of her family. Folds it gently into her back pocket. She peers out the northernmost window. Sees the library across the street. Sees Del. He’s standing on the curb, searching. He looks uneasy. Grace’s eyes dart to her suitcase. Back outside. To her surprise, Del’s staring directly up at her. He chances a wave from the curb. Grace thinks. She waves back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pairs of HANDPRINTS coat the walls in UV green and purple All shapes and sizes. Glow in the dark, psychedelic basem decor. The only hint of life in this otherwise shadowy to From above, the door CREAKS OPEN. A beam of LIGHT streaks through the dark abyss, exposing musk and rotting vapor below. Grace descends the stairs with caution. We catch quick glimpses of her face, in green and purple hues, as she passes the glowing handprints.  51. She reaches blindly. Knocks over a lava lamp. She aims her flashlight down at her feet. The shards of broken glass. The wax congealed in a fat, solid glob. It almost sounds like it’s wheezing. From upstairs:

dialogues.speaker: DEL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Everything all right?

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Yeah. I’m good. She bends down and removes the batteries from the base of broken lamp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Multiple fishing rods perch from the rim of Del’s sailboa each with a line cast out to sea. Del glares up from his book. Grace sits across from him i bathing suit top and floppy hat, engrossed in a magazine. She turns the page. Adjusts her aviators. Ignores Del. Del resumes his own reading. Suddenly, the rod at Grace’s side WOBBLES. She lowers her magazine. Looks to Del. The line TIGHTENS. The rod‘’s SLIPPING. Del’s eyes widen.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: Go--! Grace LUNGES for the ROD, the sunglasses FLYING from her face. She GRINDS IN the REEL... Another line CATCHES. Del SPRINGS to ACTION.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Del filets a tuna with a sharp knife. He cuts the hunk of fish into small slices.  52.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Del and Grace eat an elaborate sushi dinner. Grace maneuvers her chopsticks awkwardly, struggling to f the right grip on the slippery fish. Del watches her with mild amusement, using his own pair w an expert’s dexterity. Grace succeeds in guiding the tuna over her sauce tray. S gives Del a self-satisfied smirk. Her chopsticks’ hold FALTERS. The tuna PLOPS into the tra DRENCHING HER in SOY SAUCE. Grace sighs. She looks up at Del. Del neatly sets his own chopsticks aside. Reaches for the fish with his bare hands. Grace smiles. Abandons her chopsticks. Digs in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Del and Grace watch another old comedy. On the screen, some poor buffoon topples down a flight of stairs and lands in a trash can. Grace’s eyes shift to Del. He’s laughing. She follows his cue. Erupts in a belly laugh. Oversells it. Del turns to her, startled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Del and Grace play a spirited game of ping-pong. They’re both oddly adept. The ball zooms back and forth o the net, their strokes intensifying with each volley. Del hits a pop-up. Grace goes in for the kill. Puts it aw Throws her fists overhead in victory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grace scatters seeds in a pot of soil. She adorns the pot with a smiley-face sticker. Nearby, Del picks heirloom tomatoes from one of his plant  53.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A finely detailed town map hangs on the wall. Each of the cleared lots is marked with a white xX.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grace tosses Del a rolled-up trash bag, javelin-style. He catches it with one hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grace pushes a wheelbarrow packed with corpses across the front lawn. She winds past Del, who mows the grass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Del files new books into the collection. Grace whirls behind him on a hoverboard, leafing through dense manual on solar energy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Del and Grace attempt to install a set of solar panels on roof. They prove increasingly unwieldy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Del teaches Grace how to drive the street sweeper. She SLAMS her FOOT on the GAS. The vehicle HURTLES FORWAR nearly RAZING another LAMPPOST.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grace chases after a stray chicken. Panicked, the chicken averts Grace’s clutches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Del and Grace eat scrambled eggs on a park bench. Grace offers a bite to the chicken, who nips at it happil  54.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Del adjusts the angle on one of the solar panels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grace reads a magazine, feet propped up on the table. Overhead, a single light bulb SPARKS TO LIFE. Grace stares up in awe. Basks in the artificial glow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The white Xes multiply across the map.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grace rides her bike through the neighborhood. Every lawn marked, some of the Xes paled with time. She stops for a quick stretch. Notices something strange in the distance. Squints for a better look. Directly beyond her lies a DRIVEWAY partially obscured by curtain of overgrown WEEDS. Blending into the scenery. Grace wheels her bike forward. Pushes past the weeds. The driveway is ripe with cracks and fissures, a bedrock greenery fighting its way out from underneath. The path e at the foot of a decrepit HOUSE. The front door dangles off its hinges. Windows shattered. Lawn unkempt with tufts of dead grass. Grace whips out her RADIO.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Del? I found something. Over. She waits.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Come in, Del. I’m on Putnam Avenue, off of Young O. Over. Static. Grace holsters her radio. She approaches the house slowly abandoning her bike on the ground.  55.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grace wipes past a veil of cobweb. Sidesteps overturned furniture, long decayed and worn through by termites. Among the ruins: Dead plants strewn across the coffee tab Early ‘80s-era television with the screen bashed in. A goldfish lying belly-up on the surface of muck green wate

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grace wanders into the backyard, which sits at the thresh of a vast wooded wilderness. She navigates the minefield of crushed beer cans, cigaret butts and crumpled trash. An empty can of lighter fluid. Her eyes are drawn to the grill. Caught between the grate are charred flecks of paper. The mutilated remains of pag covers, bindings... They’re BOOKS. Or were. Grace turns. She comes face-to-face with a MAN, stooped i plastic lounge chair on the patio. He stares directly at her. His eyes are a pair of lifeles orbs, glazed translucent white. His mouth hangs open, showcasing a set of rotten teeth. Grace absorbs the gruesome sight. Her gaze strays downward. She spots a lone photograph, ol and faded, discarded among the garbage and dead leaves. It’s a BOY, pre-teen, standing at the edge of a lake. The same lake Del frequents. His eyes are closed.

dialogues.speaker: DEL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: This is Millburn. Not Putnam. Grace looks up. Sees Del.

dialogues.speaker: DEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I told you not to go into any of the unmarked houses alone. I told you that.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: I’m sorry.  56.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: You were never supposed to be here.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: We can clean it up. We can clear it together, just like the others.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: I don’t want it cleared. This house doesn’t get cleared. He shifts his gaze to the man in the lawn chair. His mout twists into a grimace.

dialogues.speaker: DEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This makes no fucking sense.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: It’s just a house.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: Not the house. You. You were never supposed to be here in the first place. It was just-- it was just supposed to be me.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: This, all of this, it wasn’t ever the Rapture or the bubonic plague or any of that. How do you not get it by now? (a pause) It was me. Grace’s head stirs.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: I wanted them all to go away. I wanted them to leave me alone and be gone forever. That’s what I wished for. And that’s how it happened. He sniffs in the cool air.  57.

dialogues.speaker: DEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I closed my eyes and I concentrated with every fiber of my brain and I wished for this. Exactly this.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Del.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: It’s like you said. Afterwards all I had to do was wake up and find the world changed. He laughs to himself. Grace stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: DEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I had it all worked out. It all made so much sense. Until you. See, for the life of me I can’t seem to wrap my head around just why in hell you're still here too. He shifts his balance. Rocks back and forth on his toes.

dialogues.speaker: DEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You know the first thing I saw when I woke up that day? The playground behind the old elementary school. Same school I went to as a kid. They were out for recess. His eyes start to mist.

dialogues.speaker: DEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I couldn't just leave them there like that. What kind of person would-- who would-- He falters. Grace takes a step toward him.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: You didn’t do this.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: I did. I did it.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: No you didn’t. Because then you'd really be all alone. I’d be dead with the rest of them. Del smiles sadly, lips pursed.  58.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Mhm. Grace kicks into high gear. Claps her hands together. Tie her hair up in a ponytail.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Now I don’t know about you, but I’m gonna clear this house. I’m gonna pave the driveway and pick up the trash and... and scrub the walls till they shine like the fucking Chrysler Building.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Because that’s what we do. We clear. Right? Del nods.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Right. Now let’s pick up the pace, we've got a schedule to maintain. She returns inside, a skip in her step. Del lingers in the backyard, his gaze fixed on the shreds paper in the grill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grace swiffers the floors. Collects the garbage. Sews up tears in the furniture fabric. She rolls a coat of white paint over the graffitied walls She purges the contents of the refrigerator. The pantry shelves. The dirty dishware in the sink. Among them is a cracked ceramic bowl, hand-painted with a child’s watercolor illustrations. She turns. Del’s holding the trash bag open for her.  59.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Del and Grace heave the man’s petrified corpse from the lounge chair into an open body bag. Grace musses back the man’s unruly hair. Del zips the bag shut. EXT. DEL’S TRUCK - DAY Del and Grace ride in silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Del slides the body into a fresh grave. He looks to Grace. She digs the shovel into the earth.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: Wait. He peers down into the hole. He inhales through his nose. Grace does the same. Ten seconds pass. They exhale through their mouths simultaneously.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Is that all?

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: Yeah. That’s all. He takes the shovel. Starts burying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Del marches back to the truck. Grace catches up to him.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Del? He whisks around to face her. She takes hold of his hand. Clasps it tight.  60. He glares down tensely at their intertwined fingers. Look back up at Grace. She’s staring deep into his eyes. They’re inches apart now. Del pulls her in close. Kisses her. He withdraws quickly.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Why? He thinks.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: I don’t know. INT. BEDROOM - GRACE’S HOUSE - NIGHT Del’s asleep. Peaceful. Grace lies beside him, wide awake. She veers away from him. Stares ahead solemnly. In the distance, we hear the very faint hum of a CAR ENGI

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun edges slowly over the horizon. The first rays of daylight flicker off the ocean’s surface. INT. BEDROOM - GRACE’S HOUSE - DAY Del’s eyes sway open. He shifts to Grace’s side of the bed. She’s not there. Del checks his watch. Gets up. Gathers his clothes. He hears a series of murmurs through the wood panelling i the floor. Vaguely distorted. Coming from downstairs. It’s a voice. But it’s too low to be Grace’s. He listens closer. The voice is MALE.  61. INT. STAIRWELL - GRACE’S HOUSE - DAY Del pads down the stairs. The man’s voice grows sharper.

dialogues.speaker: MAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: That’s amazing. That’s really tasty. Is that cilantro? Del approaches the dining room. He sees Grace seated at t table, her back to him.

dialogues.speaker: MAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: MAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: It is cilantro?

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: MAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I knew it. Just like they have back at the club. Cee-lan-tro. Mm. Del stops in the doorway. Grace turns to him. A full breakfast spread out on the table. Scrambled eggs hash browns. Three place settings. Three people. Across from Grace, a MAN and a WOMAN, both late 40s. Napk folded neatly into their laps. They exchange a quick look with one another.

dialogues.speaker: MAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hi there! The man gets up from his chair. His collared shirt is tuc into his pants, girding a beer belly.

dialogues.speaker: MAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Grace didn’t mention she had company. I’m Miles. Miles Mercer. Miles extends his hand outward. Del stares past him.  62.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: This is my wife Violet. Violet smiles politely. Del doesn’t reciprocate. Miles lowers his hand. He cranes his head to Grace.

dialogues.speaker: MILES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He’s not deaf, is he?

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: I think maybe he feels we're encroaching.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Ah. Well, we certainly didn’t mean to cause any trouble. We’ll be out of your hair just as soon as we’re done with our breakfast. Del glares up at him. He nods.

dialogues.speaker: MILES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Would you care to join us? Grace here prepared one hell of a meal. It'd be a shame to see it go cold.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Don’t be shy. Have a seat. Del sits at the table, his nerves flaring.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: (to Grace) Go on. Make him a plate. Del peers over at Grace. She avoids him.

dialogues.speaker: MILES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Grace. Grace abruptly grabs a plate. Shovels it full of eggs.

dialogues.speaker: MILES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So what’s your name?

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: Del.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Del what?  63.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: Just Del.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Come on. Del’s the name of my laptop. It’s gotta be short for something, hasn't it? Let’s see. Stop me when I’ve got it. Delroy? Delbert? Delano--?

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: I’m just Del.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Well, if you say so. Violet turns to Del. She speaks slowly.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: This is a lovely town, Del. Do you live here all on your own?

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: Until recently. Yes.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: And your bodies?

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: Buried.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: That’s nice.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: It’s like exactly how we do in Houston, isn’t it? Albeit on a much smaller scale-- I’m sure Grace’s told you all about Houston-- Del flinches.

dialogues.speaker: MILES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Did I say something wrong?

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: (to Grace) Who are they? Grace gazes down at her plate.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Well, we’re the Mercers. I think we already covered that.  64.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Grace, don’t bite your fingernails. Grace retracts her hands from her mouth.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: So Del, what exactly are your intentions with our daughter? Del tightens.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Excuse me. She gets up.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Sit down. She does so, reluctantly.

dialogues.speaker: MILES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to Del) You seem surprised. Has Grace not told you about us? Miles turns to Grace.

dialogues.speaker: MILES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: She's never once mentioned having had parents? No? Didn’t come up?

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: I don’t understand.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: What’s there to understand? Grace is our daughter. I’m her father. Vi's her mom. She’s our baby girl. Del processes this. They’re not the family from Grace’s photo. Not by a long shot.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: Are you sure?

dialogues.speaker: MILES
