dialogues.text: What kind of a question is that? Of course I’m sure. Tell him, Grace. Grace stares forward blankly.

dialogues.speaker: MILES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Come on. Set him straight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They’re my parents.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: I don’t think he heard you. You're gonna have to speak up.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: (louder) They’re my parents. Miles nods, satisfied.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Honey, why don’t you go upstairs and pack your bags? It’s a long ride back, and I’m playing in the tournament on Sunday.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: Tournament?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Miles is an excellent golfer.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: You don’t play, do you, Del? Del’s head stirs.

dialogues.speaker: MILES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You should consider taking it up. Back in Houston we have quite the league going.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: What do you mean, who?

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: I’1l go pack.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Wait a second.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: I need to go to the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: You can hold it. 65.  66.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: Who else is there?

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Where? You mean... you don’t know?

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: Don’t know what? Miles assesses Del, eyebrow arched.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: You’ve been alone here all this time? You haven’t-- haven’t left--?

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Didn't go out looking for other survivors...? Nothing like that?

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: No. He glares across the table at Grace. She can’t bring hers to look back at him. The color drained from her face.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: So you've been in this town all along, all on your own-- and as far as you knew you were the last man left on earth till we showed up for scrambled eggs. Miles laughs to himself.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Miles.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. It’s just, you really can’t come up with this stuff.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: We're still his guests.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: There are more of you? (to Grace) You told me--

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: What did she tell you, exactly? Del turns to Miles.  67.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: That no one else had survived. That it was just the two of us.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Now why would she go and say something like that? Grace averts his gaze.

dialogues.speaker: MILES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Two? Try hundreds. Thousands, even. And that’s just in Houston. We've got a settlement in Dallas too. Del shuts his eyes. Tries to tune him out.

dialogues.speaker: MILES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Every day brings new faces. We have signs up on practically every major highway. You can’t miss ‘em.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: I designed some myself.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Violet’s a graphic artist.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Well, I’m no Rembrandt or anything. I used to freelance for Ackerman Agency in San Diego, California. Of course, that was in my twenties... I'm rambling, aren’t I?

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: In any case, you’d be amazed to hear all we’ve accomplished in Dallas. We're rebuilding America, one sector at a time.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: Stop.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: We got the lights turned back on. Got the Internet up and running again. Phones. Power plants. Basic currency. You name it. We even recycle. Hell, we’re just about more eco-conscious than ever--

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: Stop.  Del gets up from his chair.

dialogues.speaker: DEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s time for you to leave. He glances over at Grace.

dialogues.speaker: DEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: All of you. He exits. Miles looks around the table.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Huh. Guess he’s not a recycler. He helps himself to Del’s plate. EXT. GRACE’S HOUSE - DAY Grace rushes after Del.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. Del ignores her. Keeps walking.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They’re not good people. You can’t believe what Miles says. The world they live in, it’s different from the way things were. It’s not--

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: Are they your parents?

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: I met them in Houston. They had some kind of fucked-up adoption program. You really don’t understand what it’s like down there-- I had to run away--

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: You lied to me.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: I had to.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: You would’ve never let me stay.  69.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: And fuck you?

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: I know. I know it looks bad. But after I left Houston I was on the road for months-- I hadn’t seen anyone else in all that time. Let alone in a place like this. I don’t know what I was thinking.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: You're a teenager.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: I’m nineteen. Del pauses mid-stride.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: This is all my fault. I let you in here. I trusted you.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: Y'know, this is kind of funny. It’s really actually very funny. He bites his lip. Stares Grace in the eyes.

dialogues.speaker: DEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I think you’re the worst mistake I’ve ever made.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Don’t say that.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: You should go. I really need for you to go.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: You don’t mean that. You don’t. Del shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: Go home, Grace.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Fuck you.  70.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: I’m serious. You're a selfish fucking prick and all you care about is lame old movies and-- and the Dewey fucking Decimal System. You shouldn’t even be allowed to call yourself a person. You’re a robot. You're a fucking robot incapable of human emotion. And you know what? It’s really sad. She catches her breath.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do you have anything to say?

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: Not really.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Okay. She makes for the house.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: Wait. She stops.

dialogues.speaker: DEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What was the gun for? Grace looks back at him. Her eyes are glistening.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: You don’t-- The door opens. MILES steps out onto the porch.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Sweetie, we’re just about ready to hit the road. If there’s anything else you wanted to take with you--? Grace hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: I’m coming.  71. She brushes past Miles into the house.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: How’s that for hustle? Miles flashes a friendly smile at Del. Del turns away. He walks back to the library in silence. Miles’s smile dissipates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Del works his way through a backlog of unsorted books, a welcome distraction. He inputs letters and numbers into his handheld label mak A new label sputters from his device with a protracted BE He smooths it over a book’s spine...

dialogues.speaker: MILES, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You busy? Del looks up, startled. Miles leans casually against the stacks, hands in his pockets.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Okay, don’t mind me then. I’m just looking to borrow an audiobook or two for the ride. I’1l be cooped up with two women for twenty-plus hours, Lord help me.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: Sorry. The collection’s private. He wheels a cart into the stacks. Begins filing.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: C’mon. You've got the print copies already, I’m sure. It’s just one audiobook. Give me Tuesdays with Morrie or something, I don’t care.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. Miles smirks.  72.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: It’s cool. I get it. There’s this funny thing I do, when I’m in the bathroom and the toilet paper's, like, facing the wrong way on the hook-- you know, it’s supposed to be facing out, easy access-- I’ve always gotta put it back on the right way. It’s just one of those things that freaks me out, y’know? Drives me up the friggin’ wall--

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: What does toilet paper have to do with books?

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: I’m just saying, I can appreciate a man who values order. It’s a hell of an attractive quality in a man. He gets in Del’s space. Breathes out a heavy sigh.

dialogues.speaker: MILES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You ever get sad sometimes?

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: No. Excuse me. Del separates himself, moves on to the next aisle. Miles lingers behind, kicking at the floor.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: I just-- I feel like I can talk to you, Del. Like you of all people might understand what I’m going through. The world can feel like such a messy place. A man needs to be able to wield some control over his surroundings. And I look at you and your set-up here, and I see a guy who’s got it all figured out.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: We all do what we need to do. Miles appears beside him, snapping his fingers.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Right. See, that’s exactly right. But don’t you wish everybody could see things as simply as you do?  73.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: Here everybody does.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Oh, I get it. Because it’s just you. That’s really good. Like I said, smart fuckin’ guy. He presses a finger to his temple.

dialogues.speaker: MILES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Y'know, we could use a guy like you back in Houston. Yeah, I’11l tell you, a guy with your talents would fit right in there. You could be a part of something really special, really cutting-edge...

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: No thanks. Miles stares at him for a prolonged beat. He cracks a smi

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Aw. Well, you can’t blame me for trying. Keep up the good work, Del. You've made a fan out of me. He hands Del a business card.

dialogues.speaker: MILES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Just in case you change your mind. He gives Del a sturdy pat on the shoulder, nearly knockin him off-balance. He wanders off. Del waits for Miles to exit. He glances down at the thick card stock, embossed gold lettering:

dialogues.speaker: REALIGNMENT SPECIALIST
dialogues.text: He crumples the card in his pocket. Returns to his books. INT. BEDROOM - GRACE’S HOUSE - DAY Grace strides into her bedroom. She finds Violet rifling through her suitcase, examining her clothes.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: You've got some really cute new tops here. You’ll have to let me borrow them sometime.  74.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: I have to teach you how to fold your clothes. You just ball them up like they’re garbage. It damages the material.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: You can’t just go through my things like that. You’re not my-- Violet turns to face her.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Not your what? Grace falters.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Is everything all right, honey? You sound stressed.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: I’m okay.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Really? Are you sure? She holds out the PHOTO of GRACE and HER FAMILY. Grace’s eyes go hollow.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Give it back.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: This isn’t healthy behavior, Grace. Running away from home, making us chase after you to the ends of the earth. What would your father say if he saw this picture?

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Please.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: No. I’m sorry. No. Violet tucks the photo into her bra.  75.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I had another daughter once. You know, before. It’s wrong to bring it up, I know that... She shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I can’t lose you again. I won't.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Violet.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Mom. Grace tightens.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: You know what’1l happen to me if I go back there. You know what they’11 do to me.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: You act like it’s such a bad thing.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: I’m scared.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Don’t be. I’m here for you. She wraps her arms around Grace. Brings her in close.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Everything will stop hurting soon. Grace, head pressed firm against Violet’s chest, listens the beating of her heart. EXT. GRACE’S HOUSE - DAY Miles loads Grace’s bags into the trunk of his Cadillac. sidles into the driver’s seat. Honks the horn. Violet emerges from the house, Grace in tow. Grace pauses. She looks across the street. The library sits still. No sign of life. Violet takes Grace by the arm. Ushers her into the backse  76.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Buckle up. Violet hops in the passenger’s seat. Gives Miles a peck o the cheek. Miles shifts the car into drive. Grace takes a last look at the library. He’s not coming. Miles abruptly hits the gas. SCREECH... The car peels down the street, zigs at the corner, disapp from view. A cloud of exhaust looming in its wake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Del eyes a photograph in his hands. We reverse to see: It’s the POLAROID of GRACE sticking he tongue out at the Grand Canyon. He places the photo in his filing cabinet, the newest in collection. Slides the drawer SHUT. His gaze wanders to the town map on his wall. It’s clutte with white Xes. Not an empty lot to be found. 100% clearance. He runs his hand along the map’s surface. Reaches the top TEARS IT DOWN in ONE SWIFT MOTION.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Del coasts out to sea on his sailboat. He listens as the waves beat gently against the boat’s hu The only sound for miles. He stares ahead at the horizon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door jingles as Del strides in. He stops at the liquor aisle. Processes the multitude of untouched bottles, all coated over in dust.  77.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Del cracks open a bottle of vodka. Raises it to his mouth Chugs. Chugs. Chugs. He chokes. Erupts in a coughing fit. Lets the bottle drop the ground, shattering at his feet. His eyes are watery. Bloodshot. He teeters his way to the solar panel. Paws at it with bo hands. Rends it from its hinges.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Del urinates on a patch of lawn. Crudely traces the spray painted lines of the white X. Hums a tune to himself. He hasn’t shaved in days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Del staggers down the unpaved street. Surveys the sad hou at the end of the driveway. He reaches sloppily into his waistband... Draws the HANDG from Grace’s glove compartment. He cocks the gun with effort. Steadies his aim. His finge curls the trigger... BANG. A window BURSTS INTO PIECES. He feels the rush. He fires again. Again. Again. The gunshots echo through the empty wood. Birds flee to t skies, squawking in excitement. He keeps snapping the trigger long after the chamber’s expended. His face twisted into something awful. He chucks the gun at the house.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: Fuck--! He loses his balance. Lands squarely in the dirt.

dialogues.speaker: DEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Fuck you. Fucking...  78. He tries to get up. His world is SPINNING... His legs giv out underneath him. He falls right back down. He’s filthy. Drenched from head to toe in mud and glass a snot and shit. Blistered. Bleeding. It’s not a good look. Slowly, he reclaims his wits. Focuses on breathing. Stacc and irregular grows deep and pronounced. Regaining consistency. Or a measure thereof. He cups his hands together. Spits. Rubs down his eyes wit his palms... His vision begins to steady... He hears a BA He tilts his head up. Perks his ears. Listens. Just then: A second BARK. Low. Strained. But definitely there. He looks forward. His eyes narrow. A few yards away, we can just barely make out the hazy outline of a DOG... A fat, old PUG. It’s Dewey. Del stares in awe, speechless. The corners of his mouth threatening the slightest of smiles. He chances a blink. Looks again. The dog’s gone. Disappeared without a trace. Del processes, dumbfounded.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Del ransacks his stockpile of battery-operated gadgetry. At long last, he locates his transistor radio. Mangled fr the earlier abuse. Taped together. Still workable. He powers it up. Puts his mouth to the receiver.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: Hello? He listens. Hears STATIC. Toggles to the next frequency.  79.

dialogues.speaker: DEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hello? He waits... More STATIC. It’s quiet out there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The once-clean street is littered haphazardly with crumpl papers, empty bottles and myriad miscellaneous trash. On the adjacent sidewalk, Del sits cross-legged in one of two rocking chairs. The other remains empty. He rocks gently back and forth. His face is sunburnt, his lips chapped. We get the impression he’s been stationed h for the better part of the day. Maybe longer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Del splashes his face with water. The liquid revives his cracked skin, catches in his graying beard. He submerges the buckets one by one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Del ambles through the rows of plants, spritzing each wit less care than usual. His gait is staggered, sleepy. He reaches the end of his circuit. Sees Grace’s pot of so The smiley-face sticker, grinning stupidly at him. The smallest sliver of GREEN edges out from the dirt. Del stares down at the new plant, devoid of expression. He doesn’t move for a long time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Del winds through the stacks. He stops in the geography section. Plucks out the first r atlas he sees. Flips through. Lands on a specific page.  80. His eyes dart back and forth, scanning over the complex w of routes and interstates... Fuck it. He TEARS OUT the PA It’s oddly liberating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Del blows past a stop sign. Speeds through a seemingly interminable sweep of white Xes on either side. As he accelerates, the Xes mesh into one another, forming twin solid white lines. Suddenly, he BRAKES. We're at the edge of the town. The precipice between Del’ world and the unknown. Del hesitates. Nearly chokes. He grips the wheel tight. Knuckles whitening. He wills his foot to HIT the GAS. The engine ROARS TO LIFE. Del's truck FLIES PAST the town limit, kicking up a layer of DUST that takes over frame. The dust settles... The truck’s out of sight. INT. DEL’S TRUCK - VARIOUS C.U. on DEL through the WINDSHIELD. His eyes are FIXED on THE ROAD. We, in turn, KEEP on HIM. As he soars past open country and cityscapes alike, highw and dirt road, all reflected back in the windshield’s gla As he swerves around abandoned cars and overturned tracto trailers, crumbled monuments and billowing smokestacks. As the truck battles a stretch of particularly rough terr rattling and hissing in near defeat. As day turns into night and back to day again. As a heavy thunder ripples overhead and rain beats down o the truck’s flimsy hood and the windshield wipers squeak madly against the surface of the glass. As the truck is swallowed up in thick blankets of fog, an visibility plummets to zero. Less than zero.  81. Del’s eyelids grow heavy. A five o’clock shadow transpire across his face... He doesn’t waver. Keeps the wheel stea The truck emerges triumphant from the fog -- all of a sud the windshield’s glass washes over in REFLECTIONS of LIGH A city skyline, replete with glowing buildings and pulsin neon signs and searchlights, all DANCING WILDLY ACROSS th WINDSHIELD... We KEEP on DEL. His pupils dilated from the onslaught of light. The corne of his mouth twitching ever so slightly. Betraying nothin He pushes forward in silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Del stares straight ahead. Tries to ignore the white nois a thousand disparate voices laughing, shouting, their fig drifting across the windshield all at once. A strange symphony fills our soundscape, intensifying as truck presses deeper into this urban sprawl... a rhythmic cohesion of voices, pop music, TV fuzz, iPhone ringtones. As all this BUILDS, and BUILDS, and BUILDS, Del’s fingers INTO the steering wheel... He’s LOSING IT... The sounds RISE to an all-powerful CRESCENDO, and just as looks like Del’s about to BURST, we HARD CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A modest one-story compound on the city’s outskirts. The early morning sun pokes out from over the mountainsid casting the property in dark amber tones. Del steps out from his car. Checks the address on Miles’s business card. It’s a match with the mailbox. He thinks. Doubles back. Grabs the GUN. PRE-LAP: Beep. Beep. Beep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The low hum of electricity. On the mantelpiece, a high-key photo of MILES and VIOLET.  82. The image gradually MORPHS into a portrait of the whole family. GRACE wedged uneasily between the two of them. It’s a digital picture frame, cycling through pre-loaded photos on a timer. A wire runs behind the mantel into a h surge protector, which in turn plugs into the wall. ANGLE on the FRONT DOOR. Del’s shadow manifests in the adjacent window, wielding a small screwdriver. He slips it underneath the sill... We're familiar with this routine already. The RASP of MET on WOOD. Del’s GLOVED HAND reaching inside, curling TOWAR the DOOR... TWISTING the LOCK... CLICK. Del enters. Looks around. It’s as pleasant a house as any other we’ve seen -- albeit pointedly more high-tech. The room’s centerpiece: A fireplace video, crackling on M Del removes his shoes. Sets them at the foot of the door. He moves very slowly through the house, from the living r into a long, narrow hallway marked by LED night lights. The door to the first bedroom hangs slightly ajar. He sne a peek inside... Two heaps slumped over in a king-sized b both dormant. Violet’s head poking out from under the cov Del gently shuts the door. He proceeds to the next room. Listens through the door. F the other end, we hear the light WHIRR of MACHINERY. His HAND rests on the KNOB. He TURNS... INT. GRACE’S BEDROOM - MERCER RANCH - CONTINUOUS Grace lies in bed, fast asleep. A heart rate monitor at her side, blipping softly. An IV drip. A tray of medical utensils. Some very sharp. Del approaches her bedside.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: (in SOTTO) Grace.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Mm.  83. Grace stirs. Shifts position. Turns away from Del. He looks CLOSER. A small patch of hair on the left side of Grace’s head ha been SHAVED CLEAN... There’s a fresh SCAR, approximately inches in length, on HER SCALP. Del TIGHTENS.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: Grace. It’s me. Her eyes flicker open. She stares straight past him.

dialogues.speaker: DEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m gonna get you out of here. We're gonna go home. He plucks out her IV. Holds it to her eye line.

dialogues.speaker: DEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Can you tell me what this is? Can you tell me what they’re doing--?

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Tests.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: What kinds of tests? Grace shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: DEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What’s going on? Come on. I know you can tell me what’s going on.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Tests.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: Bad tests? She gives him a blank stare.

dialogues.speaker: DEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Okay, I’m here now. It’s time to go. Let’s go. He takes her hand. She looks up at him, curious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know me. Grace shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: DEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Yeah you do. Don’t-- Stop that.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Go away. She retracts her hand.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: You know who I am.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: Yes. Yes you do. Because we’re friends. Because I drove all the way here for you... you know who I am. I’m Del, and you’re Grace, and you know who I am-- you know-- Her eyes are glazed over. Hollow.

dialogues.speaker: DEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You know me. She doesn’t flinch.

dialogues.speaker: DEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No. Don’t do that. You know who I am. You can’t-- please-- please don’t do this. Say something. Come on. Talk to me. Please... Please. A long silence hangs between them. Finally, Del pulls away.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: I think... they’1l die.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: What? He leans back in.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: The plants. 84.  85.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: What plants? My plants?

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: They’re gonna die.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: It’s okay. I watered them all right before I left. We just need to get back in time before the next cycle.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: Yeah. They’re gonna be fine. Grace smiles.

dialogues.speaker: DEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Are you ready to go?

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: I think. She sits up. Del helps her to her feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grace clutches Del’s arm for support. They push past the door to the master bedroom. Grace’s ga strays over her shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: We have to keep moving. They could wake up any second-- The FLUSH of a TOILET. A protracted YAWN. From the opposi end of the hallway. In their direct path. Del and Grace stop dead in their tracks. The bathroom door CREAKS OPEN... Grace grabs Del TIGHT... steps MILES, sleepy-eyed and scratching at his boxers. He takes a beat to register the two of them.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: We've got a doorbell, you know. He doesn’t stop scratching.  86.

dialogues.speaker: MILES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Gracie, you’re supposed to be in bed. Del, how’s about the two of us take a walk outside--?

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: We're leaving.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Leaving? But you just got here! He looks from Del to Grace. Del WHIPS

dialogues.speaker: MILES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh. I see what’s going on.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: What did you do to her?

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: She’s in the middle of an extensive treatment. I’1l just put her back to bed and afterwards I can tell you all about it-- OUT his HANDGUN.

dialogues.speaker: MILES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Whoa there. You even know how to use that thing?

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: I’m not gonna ask again.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: I mean, I’m happy to discuss it. I tried to broach the subject with you last time we met, but you didn’t seem all that interested. Honestly, I think you of all people will really appreciate this. Del lowers the gun.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: How familiar are you with the field of psychosurgery? Not the Ken Kesey stuff, I’m talking about genuine impulse correction. Realignment. We’re using the power of science to make unhappy people happier.  87.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: I don’t understand.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: We've got a team of doctors here in Houston, the best minds on the planet. They’ve come a long way toward unlocking the complexities of the human brain. Grace reaches for the scar on her head.

dialogues.speaker: MILES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s nothing to be afraid of. Very much the opposite. We’re developing a means by which to control for all types of disorders. Schizophrenia. Depression. Suicidal thoughts. He takes a step forward.

dialogues.speaker: MILES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Picture a world where those nasty elements simply don’t exist. Where disorder’s translated into order. Where every human mind’s free from pain. Free from angst and sadness and-- and all-around chaos. It’d be, well, you could say it’s--

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: Perfect.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Exactly. It’s practically a return to Eden. I’m glad you came here, Del. That you’re able to see it all firsthand. I'd like to have you involved as we move forward. I think together we can accomplish some really wonderful stuff--

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: No. We're going. Excuse us.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: You're just gonna leave?  88. Miles blocks their path.

dialogues.speaker: MILES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Now see, I’ve got a problem with that. A man doesn’t just go and break into another man’s home, steal away his daughter and expect no pushback on the matter. No way. I’m gonna fuckin’ fight you on that one, Del. And I’m gonna win too. He peers over at Grace.

dialogues.speaker: MILES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sweetie, why don’t you head on back to bed? You know you’ve got another round of treatment in the morning-- Grace SNATCHES the GUN from DEL’S BELT in ONE SWIFT MOTIO Before EITHER MAN can REACT -- BLAM! Miles’s HEAD EXPLODES in a MESS of BLOOD and BRAINS. Grace straightens her posture. She and Del both stares do at the corpse, neither showing any visible reaction. The door behind them opens. They turn to see VIOLET, clad her pajamas. Rubbing her eyes. Exhausted. She gazes past them at Miles’s body.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Oh, honey.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Where’s my photo?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Which photo?

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: The one you took from me. Violet looks up at Grace.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: That photo’s long gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Del hastens to the front door, leaving behind a trail of blood-soaked shoe prints.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: Are you coming? Grace remains in the hallway, the gun limp at her side. She turns

dialogues.speaker: DEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Grace--?

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: We have to get rid of them. to Del.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: When they find the bodies, they’1l open an investigation. They know who I am. They’1ll come after us.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: Who will?

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Do you really want to know? Del considers this.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We have a few hours before anyone else shows up. We need to make it look like they left town.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: There should be trash bags and cleaning supplies in the garage. They might have some extra paint back there too.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: Where’s that? Grace points. Del heads for the door.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Hey Del? I’m sorry I shot them. Del stops. He looks back at her.  90.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: No you're not.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Is that okay?

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: I think so. Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Del yanks out the shower curtain. He and Grace slide Violet’s body onto the plastic. Her he is covered with a SKI MASK drenched in BLOOD. They roll her into a tight cocoon. Secure it in place wit one, two, three layers of packing tape. They fold Miles’s body into a bearskin rug. His head, or thereof, also MASKED. Grace sprays the floor with a cleaning solution. Sops up bloody footprints with a fat sponge. Del picks at the flecks of brain matter in the wall with pair of tweezers. Deposits them in a trash bag. Grace dances around him, erasing any and all traces of bl with a fresh coat of white paint. Del peruses Miles’s library. Picks out a book he doesn’t recognize. Reads the dust jacket. Tosses it in his backpa Grace powers down the medical equipment. Changes the shee on her bed. Smooths out the creases in the fabric. Del heaves two bulging trash bags into the back of his tr Miles and Violet’s burritoed bodies are already buckled i Grace jerks the plug from the digital picture frame. Mi a Vi's smiling faces ZAP to BLACK. Del activates the kitchen faucet. Marvels at the sight of running water. Cranes his head downward... Lets the liqui flow freely over his face. Drinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Del exits the house. He sees Grace in the front yard, the paint bin at her side.  gl. He walks over to her. She holds out a damp brush. Del thinks. He takes the brush from Grace. Kneels into th dirt. Paints a long, thick STRIP of WHITE. Then ANOTHER. He pulls back, revealing an X.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: Ready?

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Almost.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grace beelines to the freezer. Flings the drawer open. From FREEZER POV, we look up at Grace’s face, awash in a orange light. She smiles wide. INT. DEL’S TRUCK - DAY Del and Grace hit the road. The city skyline fades to nothingness in the back windshield. Grace cradles a mammoth bucket of Neapolitan ice cream in lap. Devouring it by the spoonful. She offers Del a scoop. He pulls his head away from her.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: You’re gonna use the same spoon? Grace's smile fades.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: You must be joking. He keeps his eyes on the road. Doesn’t respond.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You are joking, right? Please tell me you’re... Del? Del peers over at her. He cracks a smile.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You asshole. ROLL CREDITS.
